Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Expectation2: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation2: The project is still in exploratory discussions, and alternative approaches can be proposed later
Story: I stared at my phone, the group chat buzzing with messages from my siblings. Mom had planned a small family dinner tonight, and everyone was expected to be there. My sister sent a photo of the table already set, and I could almost smell the familiar dishes. I knew how much these gatherings meant to my family, especially after how busy we’d all been lately. But at the same time, my laptop screen glowed with diagrams and notes from the project team. We were still in the early stages, tossing around ideas for a new design, and I felt the pressure to contribute something innovative. My manager had hinted that fresh perspectives were needed, and I didn’t want to seem disengaged. I could hear my family laughing in the background as I weighed my options, feeling the tug of responsibility from both sides. The guilt of possibly letting someone down—either my family or my team—gnawed at me, and I sat frozen, torn between the warmth of home and the drive to prove myself at work.
